page.lettertext:
fol.161r
Belgia [.] June To my L. Trea
s
Belgia: 1591: June:
May it please yo
r
good L. It is now determined
at the
Towne of
Groeningh
e
shalbe p
nt
ly attempted, for w
ch
8 Troupes are risen & m
r
ching alredy, Theyr artillery
is emb
r
qued & sent awaie before, But wheth
r
they will
use
e benefit of her
Hig
nes
l
re
s, w
ch
were written so long
since, & I have still in my custody I cannot redyly
conjecture. But being often required by
e
Councels
l
re
s
to repayre unto them, I think they have a meaning when no
oth
r
meanes will
s
ve
e turne, to use
e countenance of her
Ma
tye
, if it come to that passe, I will advise upon
e best, for her Hig
nes
contenta
o
n. For I have seen by
good tokens that
Count William
is affrayd, to be set beside
e governm
t
, if the towne be returned by her Ma
t
authority
for w
ch
I think hee will endevo
r
to p
r
vaile an other way.
The
ty w
ch
I employed about
e recovery of those
papers & bookes that came out of
Spaine,
hath spedd
of his purpose, & hath all alredy in his custody.
Because his dwelling is in
Amsterdam,
& my waie into
Frise
(where I thinke w
th
in this 2 daies to meet
e
Councel) is by Amsterdam, I will take
e writing
to
my self & convay them from thence by
e speediest
meanes that I can finde. The bearer heerof ys the
broth
r
of
Cap
t
Medekerk
, that was slaine of late in
e siege of
Deventer,
hee comes an humble suto
r
to
yo
r
L. to obtene his brothers place, w
ch
in
e jugement of
those
t
have seen his valiant carriage, hee will deserve
in all respect
aswell as his brother, w
ch
being notefied
unto mee by those
t
know his sufficiency I could not but
report yt, & recomend him effectually to yo
r
L. favo
r
.
This day I have written a l
re
to yo
r
L. by an english
souldier, w
ch
came heth
r
from
Bruxels,
where he sayth he
had bin prisoner, 5 weekes, his coming to me was for a
lett
r
to yo
r
L. or to some oth
r
of my LL of
e Councell
to
e end hee might be heard in disclosing a practise
of
among
e fugitifs of Bruxels, for
e setting a fire of her
Ma
t
shippes. Since is going from hence I have learned
fol.161v
To my L. T
re
r 6 June 1591
Belgia: 1591: June
by enquiry, that he caried about him a bagg full of
dallers, to a farr greater somme then a souldier, & a man
of simpler quality & shew should seeme to have gotten
unles he were hired to speciall purpose. Being asked of
one
t
saw his mony what he ment to cary so much about
him, his answere was that
S
r
Robert Sidney
had put him
in trust to pay it at
e campe, w
th
sundry other vayn &
unprobable speeches. W
ch
I thought good to im
te to yo
r
L.
becaus yt carieth suspition of some thing els intended then
the service hee professeth.
